snippet: Research on how food preferences develop suggests that obesity may have its roots in what we eat as babies.
abstract: Op-Ed article by journalist Kristin Wartman observes researchers have found evidence that suggests children develop food preferences in utero, which has profound implications for obesity rates and the future health of Americans; contends in order to reverse the tide on obesity and diet-related disease, regulating processed food products and infant formula will be necessary.
lead_paragraph: Research on how food preferences develop suggests that obesity may have its roots in what we eat as babies.

headline.main: Bad Eating Habits Start in the Womb
headline.print_headline: Bad Eating Habits Start in the Womb
